pli-tv-pvr7:28.1: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of condemnation against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.2: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.3: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of demotion against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.4: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.6: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of banishing him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.7: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.9: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of reconciliation against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.10: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.12: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of ejecting him for not recognizing an offense:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.13: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.15: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of ejecting him for not making amends for an offense:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.16: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.18: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of ejecting him for not giving up a bad view:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.19: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.1: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, plan a strong action against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.2: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.3: When a monk has three qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.4: he is shameless, ignorant, and not a regular monk.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.5: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.6: he has failed in the higher morality; he has failed in conduct; he has failed in view.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.7: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.8: his bodily conduct is frivolous; his verbal conduct is frivolous; his bodily and verbal conduct are frivolous.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.9: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.10: he is improperly behaved by body; he is improperly behaved by speech; he is improperly behaved by body and speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.11: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.12: his bodily conduct is harmful; his verbal conduct is harmful; his bodily and verbal conduct are harmful.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.13: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.14: he has wrong livelihood by body; he has wrong livelihood by speech; he has wrong livelihood by body and speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.15: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.16: if, after committing an offense and having a legal procedure done against him, he: (1) gives the full ordination, (2) gives formal support, (3) has a novice monk attend on him.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.17: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.18: he commits the same offense for which the Sangha did the legal procedure against him; he commits an offense similar to the one for which the Sangha did the legal procedure against him; he commits an offense worse than the one for which the Sangha did the legal procedure against him.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.19: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.20: he disparages the Buddha; he disparages the Teaching; he disparages the Sangha.

pli-tv-pvr7:33.13: for the restraint of bad people; for the ease of good monks, stopping those with bad desires from creating a faction and then splitting the Sangha; and out of compassion for families.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.8: There are rules that have variety in the action that is the basis for the offense, but not in the offense; there are rules that have variety in the offense, but not in the action that is the basis for the offense; there are rules that have variety both in the action that is the basis for the offense and in the offense; there are rules that have variety neither in the action that is the basis for the offense nor in the offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.9: There are rules where the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, but not the offense; there are rules where the offense is shared, but not the action that is the basis for the offense; there are rules where both the action that is the basis for the offense and the offense are shared; there are rules where neither the action that is the basis for the offense nor the offense is shared.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.10: There are offenses committed by the preceptor, but not the student; there are offenses committed by the student, but not the preceptor; there are offenses committed by both the preceptor and the student; there are offenses committed by neither the preceptor nor the student.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.11: There are offenses committed by the teacher, but not the pupil; there are offenses committed by the pupil, but not the teacher; there are offenses committed by both the teacher and the pupil; there are offenses committed by neither the teacher nor the pupil.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.12: There is no offense for breaking the rainy-season residence for these four reasons:
pli-tv-pvr7:50.13: there is a schism in the Sangha; there are some some who wants to create a schism in the Sangha; there is a danger to life; there is a danger to living the spiritual life.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.14: There are four kinds of bad conduct by speech:
pli-tv-pvr7:50.15: lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and idle speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.16: There are four kinds of good conduct by speech:
pli-tv-pvr7:50.17: truthful speech, non-divisive speech, gentle speech, and meaningful  speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.18: There are offenses that are serious when doing them oneself, but light when inciting someone else.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.19: There are offenses that are light when doing them oneself, but serious when inciting someone else. There are offenses that are serious both when doing them oneself and when inciting someone else.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.20: There are offenses that are light both when doing them oneself and when inciting someone else.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.1: There are people who deserve being bowed down to, but not being stood up for.

pli-tv-pvr7:52.7: There are four ways of acting that are wrong:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.8: acting from desire, acting from ill will, acting from confusion, and acting from fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.9: There are four ways of acting that are not wrong:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.10: not acting from desire, not acting from ill will, not acting from confusion, and not acting from fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.11: When a shameless monk who has four qualities, he causes a schism in the Sangha:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.12: he acts from desire, he acts from ill will, he acts from confusion, and he acts from fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.13: When a good monk who has four qualities, he unites a divided Sangha:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.14: he does not act from desire, he does not act from ill will, he does not act from confusion, and he does not act from fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.15: When a monk has four qualities, he should not be asked about the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.16: he acts from desire, he acts from ill will, he acts from confusion, and he acts from fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.17: When a monk has four qualities, he should not ask about the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.18: he acts from desire, he acts from ill will, he acts from confusion, and he acts from fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.19: When a monk has four qualities, he should not reply to questions about the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.20: he acts from desire, he acts from ill will, he acts from confusion, and he acts from fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.21: When a monk has three qualities, his questions about the Monastic Law should not be replied to:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.22: he acts from desire, he acts from ill will, he acts from confusion, and he acts from fear.

pli-tv-pvr7:52.26: he acts from desire, he acts from ill will, he acts from confusion, and he acts from fear.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.1: There are five kinds of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.2: There are five classes of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.3: There are five grounds of training.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.4: There are five kinds of action with results in the next life.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.5: There are five kinds of people with fixed rebirth.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.6: There are five offenses involving cutting down.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.7: There are five reasons for committing an offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.8: There are five kinds of offenses because of lying.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.9: There are five reasons why a legal procedure is invalid:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.10: one does not do the legal procedure oneself; or one does not request someone else; one does not give one’s consent or declare one’s purity; one objects while the legal procedure is being carried out; or one has the view that the completed legal procedure is illegitimate.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.11: There are five reasons why a legal procedure is valid:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.12: one does the legal procedure oneself; or one requests someone else; one gives one’s consent or declares one’s purity; one does not object while the legal procedure is being carried out; or one has the view that the completed legal procedure is legitimate.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.13: There are five things that are allowable for a monk who is eating almsfood:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.14: visiting families before or after a meal invitation, eating in a group, eating a meal before another, non-determination, non-transfer.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.15: When a monk has five qualities—whether he is bad or firm in morality—he is suspected and mistrusted:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.16: he regularly associates with prostitutes, widows, young unmarried women, eunuchs, or nuns.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.17: There are five kinds of oil:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.18: sesame oil, mustard-seed oil, honey-tree oil, castor oil, and oil from fat.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.19: There are five kinds of fat:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.20: bear fat, fish fat, alligator fat, pig fat, and donkey fat.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.21: There are five kinds of loss:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.22: loss of relatives, loss of property, loss of health, loss in morality, and loss of view.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.23: There are five kinds of prosperity:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.24: prosperity in relatives, prosperity in property, prosperity in health, prosperity in morality, and prosperity in view.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.25: There are five reasons why the formal support of a preceptor comes to an end:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.26: the preceptor goes away; the preceptor disrobes; the preceptor dies; the preceptor joins another faction; or the preceptor gives an order.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.27: There are five kinds of people who should not be given the full ordination:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.28: one lacking in age, one lacking in limbs, one who is deficient as object, one who has acted wrongly, and one who is incomplete.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.29: There are five kinds of rags:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.30: those from a charnel ground, those from a shop, those eaten by rats, those eaten by termites, those burnt by fire.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.31: There are five other kinds of rags:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.32: those chewed by cattle, those chewed by goats, those left at a stupa, those discarded from a king's consecration, those taken to and then brought back from a charnel ground.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.33: There are five kinds of removing:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.34: removing by theft, removing by force, removing dependent on conditions, removing by concealing, removing by drawing lots.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.35: There are five great gangsters to be found in the world.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.36: There are five things not to be given away.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.37: There are five things not to be shared out.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.38: There are five kinds of offenses that originate from body, not from speech and mind.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.39: There are five kinds of offenses that originate from body and speech, not from mind.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.40: There are five kinds of offenses that are confessable.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.41: There are five kinds of Sangha.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.42: There are five ways of reciting the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.43: In all outlying countries, the full ordination is to be given by a group of five, including one expert on the Monastic Law.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.44: There are five benefits of doing the robe-making procedure.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.45: There are five kinds of legal procedures.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.46: There are five “up to three times” offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.47: When five factors are fulfilled,  there is an offense entailing expulsion for one who steals.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.48: When five factors are fulfilled, there is a serious offense for one who steals.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.49: When five factors are fulfilled, there is an offense of wrong conduct for one who steals.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.50: There are five unallowable things that should not be used:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.51: what has not been given, what is not known about, what is not allowable, what has not been received, and what has not been “made leftover”.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.52: There are five allowable things that may be used:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.53: what has been given, what is known about, what is allowable, what has been received, and what has been “made leftover”.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.54: There are five gifts without merit that are considered meritorious in the world:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.55: alcohol, entertainment, a woman, a bull, and a picture.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.56: There are five things that are hard to remove:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.57: desire, ill will, confusion, the desire to speak, and the thought of departing.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.58: There are five benefits of sweeping:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.59: one’s own mind becomes serene, the minds of others become serene, the gods are pleased, one accumulates actions that lead to being inspiring, at the break-up of the body after death one is reborn in heaven.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.60: There are five other benefits of sweeping:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.61: one’s own mind becomes serene, the minds of others become serene, the gods are pleased, one carries out the Teacher’s instruction, later generations follow one’s example.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.2: he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.3: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.4: he grasps what is proper for himself to say; he grasps what is proper for others to say; grasping both, he makes them act legitimately, in accordance with their admission.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.5: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.6: he does not know the offenses, he does not know the source of offenses, he does not know the origin of offenses, he does not know the ending of offenses, he does not know the path leading to the ending of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.7: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.8: he knows the offenses, he knows the source of offenses, he knows the origin of offenses, he knows the ending of offenses, he knows the path leading to the ending of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.9: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.11: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.12: he knows legal issues, he knows the source of legal issues, he knows the origin of legal issues, he knows the ending of legal issues, he knows the path leading to the ending of legal issues.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.13: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.14: he does not know the actions that are the basis for offenses, he does not know the origin stories, he does not know the rules, he does not know the additions to the rules, he does not know the sequence of statements.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.15: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.16: he knows the actions that are the basis for offenses, he knows the origin stories, he knows the rules, he knows the additions to the rules, he knows the sequence of statements.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.18: he does not know the motion, he does not know how the motion is done, he is not skilled in what comes first, he is not skilled in what comes afterwards, he does not know the right time.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.19: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.20: he knows the motion, he knows how the motion is done, he is skilled in what comes first, he is skilled in what comes afterwards, he knows the right time.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.21: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.23: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.24: he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he has well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.25: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.26: he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; he does not know the light and heavy offenses; he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; he does not know the grave and minor offenses; he has not properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, not having well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.27: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.28: he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, having well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.29: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.30: he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; he does not know the light and heavy offenses; he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; he does not know the grave and minor offenses; he is not skilled in legal issues and deliberations.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.31: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.32: he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he is skilled in legal issues and deliberations.
pli-tv-pvr7:65.1: There are five kinds of wilderness dwellers:
pli-tv-pvr7:65.2: one may be a wilderness dweller because of stupidity and folly; because one is overcome by bad desires; because of insanity and derangement; because it is praised by the Buddhas and their disciples; or because of fewness of wishes, contentment, self-elimination, seclusion, and wanting it.

pli-tv-pvr7:66.1: When a monk has five qualities, he should not live without formal support:
pli-tv-pvr7:66.2: he does not know about the observance day; he does not know the observance-day procedure; he does not know the Monastic Code; he does not know the recitation of the Monastic Code; he has less than five years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:67.1: There are five dangers in being uninspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.2: You criticize yourself; after investigating, wise people condemn you; you get a bad reputation; you die confused; after death, you are reborn in a lower realm.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.3: There are five benefits in being inspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.4: You do not criticize yourself; after investigating, wise people praise you; you get a good reputation; you die unconfused; after death, you are reborn in heaven.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.5: There are five other dangers in being uninspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.6: you hinder confidence in those without it; you cause some with confidence to change their minds;  you don’t carry out the Teacher’s instructions; later generations follow your example; your mind doesn’t become serene.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.7: There are five benefits in being inspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.8: you give rise confidence in those without it; you increase the confidence of those who have it; you carry out the Teacher’s instructions; later generations follow your example; your mind becomes serene.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.9: There are five dangers in associating with families:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.10: he commits the offense of visiting families before or after a meal invitation; he commits the offense of sitting in private with a woman; he commits the offense of sitting on a concealed seat with a woman; he commits the offense of teaching more than five or six sentences to a woman; he has a lot of sensual thoughts.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.11: There are five dangers for a monk who associates with families:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.12: when he associates too much with families, he often sees women; because of seeings them, he associates with them; because of associating with them, there is intimacy; because of intimacy, there is weakness; because his mind is overcome by lust, it is to be expected that he will be dissatisfied with the spiritual life, that he commits a certain defiled offense, or that he will renounce the training and return to the lower life.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.1: There are five kinds of propagation:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.2: propagation from roots, propagation from stems, propagation from joints, propagation from cuttings, and propagation from regular seeds as the fifth.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.3: When fruit is allowable for ascetics for any of five reasons, it may be eaten:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.4: it has been damaged by fire, it has been damaged by a knife, it has been damaged by a nail, it’s seedless, the seeds have been removed.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.5: There are five kinds of purification:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.6: After reciting the introduction, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.7: After reciting the introduction  and the four rules entailing expulsion, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.8: After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, and the thirteen rules entailing suspension, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.9: After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, the thirteen rules entailing suspension, and the two undetermined rules, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.11: There are five other kinds of purification:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.12: the observance-day procedure which consists of reciting the Monastic Code,  the observance-day procedure which consists of declaring purity, the observance-day procedure which consists of a determination, the invitation procedure, and the unity observance day as the fifth.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.13: There are five benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.14: your own morality is well guarded; you ; you ar a refuge for those who are habitually anxious; you speak with confidence in the midst of the Sangha; you can legitimately and properly refute an opponent;  you are practicing for the longevity of the true Teaching.

pli-tv-pvr7:97.1: When a monk has seven qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:97.2: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the  non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He is virtuous and restrained by the Monastic Code. His conduct is good, he associates with the right people, and he sees danger in minor faults. And he undertakes and trains in the training rules. (6) Whenever he wants, he accesses the higher mind, the four absorptions, those pleasant hangouts of the present life. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.
pli-tv-pvr7:98.1: When a monk has seven other qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:98.2: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the  non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He has learned much, and he retains and accumulates what he has learned. Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, that have a true goal and are well articulated, and that set out the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life—he has learned many such teachings, retained them in mind, recited them verbally, mentally investigated them, and penetrated them well by view. (6) Whenever he wants, he accesses the higher mind, the four absorptions, those pleasant hangouts of the present life. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:99.2: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the  non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition. (6) Whenever he wants, he accesses the higher mind, the four absorptions, those pleasant hangouts of the present life. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.
pli-tv-pvr7:100.1: When a monk has seven other qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:100.2: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the  non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He recollects many past lives, that is, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, and many eons of world dissolution, many eons of world evolution, and many eons of both dissolution and evolution, and he knows: ʻThere I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span. Passing away from there, I was reborn elsewhere, and there I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.’ In this way he recollects many past lives with their characteristics and particulars. (6) With superhuman and purified clairvoyance, he sees beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions: ‘These beings who engaged in misconduct by body, speech, and mind, who abused the noble ones, who had wrong views and acted accordingly, at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a lower realm, a bad destination, a world of misery, hell. But these beings who engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not abuse the noble ones, who held right view and acted accordingly, at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’ In this way, with superhuman and purified clairvoyance, he sees beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:126.14: If he is possessed of ten qualities a novice should be expelled.
pli-tv-pvr7:127.1: If he is possessed of ten qualities an expert on Discipline is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:127.2: if he does not put a limit to his own speech, if he does not put a limit to the speech of another (person), if, not having put a limit to his own speech, to the speech of another (person), he has a (formal) act carried out not according to rule, not with his acknowledgement, if does not know what is an offence, if he does not know what is the root of an offence, if he does not know the arising … the stopping … the course leading to the stopping of an offence.
pli-tv-pvr7:128.1: If he is possessed of ten qualities an expert on Discipline is reckoned as clever:
pli-tv-pvr7:128.2: if he puts a limit to his own speech … if he knows what is an offence … the course leading to the stopping of an offence.
pli-tv-pvr7:129.1: And if he is possessed of ten further qualities an expert on Discipline is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:129.2: if he does not know what is a legal question … the root of a legal question … the arising … the stopping … the course leading to the stopping of a legal question, if he does not know the subject … the provenance … the laying down … the supplementary laying down … the sequence of the connecting words.
pli-tv-pvr7:130.1: If he is possessed of ten qualities an expert on Discipline is reckoned as clever:
pli-tv-pvr7:130.2: if he knows what is a legal question … the sequence of the connecting words.
pli-tv-pvr7:131.1: And if he is possessed of ten further qualities an expert on Discipline is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:131.2: if he does not know what is a motion, if he does not know the carrying out of a motion, if he is not skilled in what comes first, if he is not skilled in what comes afterwards, and if he is one unknowing of the (right) time, if he does not know what is an offence and what is not an offence, if he does not know a slight and a serious offence, if he does not know what is an offence that can be done away with and one that cannot be done away with, if he does not know what is a very bad offence and one that is not very bad, if he has not learnt properly from a succession of teachers, has not attended properly, has not reflected on properly.
pli-tv-pvr7:132.1: If he is possessed of ten qualities an expert on, Discipline is reckoned as clever:
pli-tv-pvr7:132.2: if he knows what is a motion … if he has learnt properly from a succession of teachers, has attended properly, has reflected on properly.
pli-tv-pvr7:133.1: And if he is possessed of ten further qualities an expert on Discipline is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:133.2: if he does not know what is an offence and what is not an offence, if he does not know a slight and a serious offence, if he does not know what is an offence that can be done away with and one that cannot be done away with, if he does not know what is a very bad offence and one that is not very bad, and if the two _Pātimokkhas_ in full have not been properly handed down to him, not properly sectioned, not properly regulated, not properly investigated clause by clause and in respect of the linguistic form, if he does not know what is an offence and what is not an offence … if he does not know what is a very bad offence and one that is not very bad, and if he is not skilled in investigating a legal question.
pli-tv-pvr7:134.1: If he is possessed of ten qualities … clever:
pli-tv-pvr7:134.2: if he knows what is an offence … and if he is skilled in investigating a legal question.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.1: A monk possessed of ten qualities may be agreed upon for a referendum.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.2: Dependent on ten reasons a rule of training for disciples is laid down by the Tathāgata.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.3: Ten perils in entering a king’s women’s quarters.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.7: One may ordain through a group of ten (monks).
pli-tv-pvr7:135.9: Wearers of ten colours for robes.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.10: One may wear an extra robe for at most ten days.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.15: Ten individuals who are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.17: One brings slander in ten ways.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.20: Ten suspensions of the _Pātimokkha_ are not legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.21: Ten suspensions of the _Pātimokkha_ are legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.23: Ten (kinds of) flesh are not allowed.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.25: An experienced competent monk who is of ten years’ standing may let go forth, may ordain, may give guidance, a novice may attend him.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.26: An experienced competent nun who is of ten years’ standing may let go forth … a woman novice may attend her.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.27: Agreement to ordain may be accepted by an experienced competent nun who is of ten years’ standing.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.28: Training should be given to a girl who has been married for ten years.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.1: Eleven individuals who, if they have not been ordained, should not be ordained; if they have been ordained, they should be expelled.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.2: Eleven (kinds of) shoes are not allowable.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.3: Eleven (kinds of) bowls are not allowable.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.9: On the eleventh day at sunrise it is an offence of expiation involving forfeiture.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.12: Eleven (kinds of) earth are not allowable.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.15: Eleven individuals are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.19: Eleven perils to be expected for an individual who reviles and abuses.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.20: If the freedom of mind that is loving-kindnessis practised, developed, made much of, made a basis, made a vehicle, persisted in, become familiar with and well established, eleven advantages are to be expected:
pli-tv-pvr7:144.21: one sleeps in comfort, wakes in comfort, dreams no evil dream, is dear to human beings, dear to non-human beings, _devatās_ guard him, fire poison and weapons do not affect him, his mind is easily concentrated, the expression on his face is serene, he does his (karmic) time unconfused, and if he penetrates no higher (to arahantship than the attainment of loving-kindness) he reaches the Brahma-world (on deceasing from this life).
pli-tv-pvr7:144.22: If the freedom of mind that is loving-kindness is practised … well established, these eleven advantages are to be expected.
